column4: Does unetbootin need enough space on the OS drive to process the transfer?
The situation is, I have a very very old crappy borrowed PC, and a new PC with almost all the parts I need. I need a OS for my new PC.
This ancient PC lacks a burning drive, and has very crowded tiny hard drives
Well, the linux is for the new PC, not the old one, I just need to get it to the new one
So unetbootin doesn't turn the flash drive into a phantom DVD image where the rest of the space disappears then, right?
Lexvegas: and the unitbootin process doesn't delete any data or require a empty USB flash, right?
POST beeps (if PC speakers are plugged in) are the primary way to diagnose major system problems
Lexvegas: Well if your not positive
Another issue though, doesn't the OS drive need X amount of temporary space to process the unetbootin conversion process?
GRUB2 can allow you to boot from an iso that's already on the flash drive.
I didn't fully understand what you mean

GRUB2 is a bootloader. You can install GRUB2 to a flash drive and manually configure it to boot from an Ubuntu iso file on that same flash drive (without needing to extract or do anything else to the iso).
It is much more work than tools like unetbootin, but it doesn't require copying / modification of the contents of the iso itself.
How is it more work? Any other catches?
It's more work because it's not a nice GUI designed specifically for the purpose. You need to use terminal commands and text configuration files to set it up.
Hmm, I have never ever used linux before though, that sounds a bit scary.
Indeed, it's probably not something you want to do as a beginner.
